channel.title: "Java" Isnt recognized
channel.description:
Say's it all in the title. I have JDK and JRE.
[IMG]http://i.imgur.com/jqnxJ.png[/img]
Help?

item.title: "Java" Isnt recognized
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Post the value of the “JAVA_HOME” variable you created

Read full topic

item.title: "Java" Isnt recognized
item.dc:creator: @fourscape fourscape
item.description:
@fourscape wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:5, topic:465707”][quote author=fourscape link=topic=571777.msg4136876#msg4136876 date=1351792126]

  1. Go to your java directory
  2. Go to your JDK directory
  3. Go to the bin folder
  4. Right-click the “java” executable file
  5. Click “Properties”
  6. Copy the Location
  7. Click the Start menu
  8. Right click on Computer
  9. Go to Properties
  10. Click “Advanced system settings” on the left
  11. Click “Environment variables”
  12. Click the “New…” Button under the System Variables
  13. Set variable name as “JAVA_HOME”
  14. Paste in the Location you copied in step 6 to the “Variable value” field
  15. Click “Ok”
  16. Select the “Path” variable under the System Variables.
  17. Click the “Edit…” button
  18. Add “;%JAVA_HOME%” to the end of the “Variable value” field
  19. Click “Ok”
  20. Click “Ok”
  21. Run your batch file again.

Nope, didden’t work.
[/quote]

If you did all of those things, exactly as written, then there is no reason that it shouldn’t work, because I did it myself while writing it.

Are you still getting the same error?[/quote]

Yup, same error.

Read full topic

item.title: "Java" Isnt recognized
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus

[quote=“fourscape, post:3, topic:465707”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=571777.msg4136855#msg4136855 date=1351790834]

  1. Go to your java directory
  2. Go to your JDK directory
  3. Go to the bin folder
  4. Right-click the “java” executable file
  5. Click “Properties”
  6. Copy the Location
  7. Click the Start menu
  8. Right click on Computer
  9. Go to Properties
  10. Click “Advanced system settings” on the left
  11. Click “Environment variables”
  12. Click the “New…” Button under the System Variables
  13. Set variable name as “JAVA_HOME”
  14. Paste in the Location you copied in step 6 to the “Variable value” field
  15. Click “Ok”
  16. Select the “Path” variable under the System Variables.
  17. Click the “Edit…” button
  18. Add “;%JAVA_HOME%” to the end of the “Variable value” field
  19. Click “Ok”
  20. Click “Ok”
  21. Run your batch file again.
    [/quote]

Nope, didden’t work.[/quote]

If you did all of those things, exactly as written, then there is no reason that it shouldn’t work, because I did it myself while writing it.

Are you still getting the same error?

Read full topic
